name: The Fire Archetype
definition: Fire represents the archetypal force of transformation, purification, and illumination across human cultures. As one of the four classical elements, fire embodies the dynamic principle of change - neither creating nor destroying matter but fundamentally altering its form and releasing energy in the process. The fire archetype appears universally in mythology as both beneficent giver of civilization and terrifying agent of destruction, reflecting humanity's ambivalent relationship with this elemental power that lifted us above other animals while also threatening our existence.

characteristics.name: Transformation
characteristics.description: Fire changes everything it touches, burning away the old to make way for the new. This represents death and rebirth, the destruction necessary for creation.
characteristics.psychologicalMeaning: Personal transformation, burning away old patterns and beliefs

characteristics.name: Purification
characteristics.description: Sacred flames cleanse sin, impurity, and corruption. Fire sterilizes, purifies metals, and releases the essence of sacrificial offerings.
characteristics.psychologicalMeaning: Catharsis, releasing toxic emotions, spiritual cleansing

characteristics.name: Destruction
characteristics.description: Divine wrath manifested as consuming fire that obliterates enemies. Fire as weapon of gods and ultimate threat.
characteristics.psychologicalMeaning: Destructive anger, the shadow side of passion, necessary endings

characteristics.name: Passion
characteristics.description: The burning intensity of desire, rage, and creative fervor. Fire as metaphor for emotional intensity.
characteristics.psychologicalMeaning: Creative drive, sexual energy, enthusiasm, anger

characteristics.name: Illumination
characteristics.description: Fire brings light to darkness, revealing truth and dispelling ignorance. The first technology of enlightenment.

characteristics.name: Sacrifice
characteristics.description: The altar flame that carries offerings to the divine realm. Fire as mediator between worlds.
characteristics.psychologicalMeaning: Letting go of attachments, offering oneself to higher purpose

characteristics.name: Forge
characteristics.description: Creative fire that shapes metal, pottery, and civilization itself. The controlled use of destructive power for creation.
characteristics.psychologicalMeaning: Craftsmanship, discipline, transforming raw material into art

characteristics.name: Sun
characteristics.description: The celestial fire that gives life and marks time's passage. The divine fire in the sky.
characteristics.psychologicalMeaning: Consciousness, life energy, the Self in Jungian terms

characteristics.name: Life Force
characteristics.description: The vital spark that animates living beings. Fire as the principle that distinguishes life from death.
characteristics.psychologicalMeaning: Vitality, enthusiasm, the spark of life and creativity

characteristics.name: Danger
characteristics.description: Untamed fire that devours forests, cities, and worlds. The terrifying aspect of this elemental power.
characteristics.psychologicalMeaning: Fear of loss of control, the destructive potential in all transformation

James Frazer - The Golden Bough (fire rituals section)
Mircea Eliade - The Forge and the Crucible
analysis: Fire represents the first technology that separated humans from animals, enabling cooking, warmth, protection from predators, and the extension of activity into night.
The ambivalent nature of fire - both life-giving and death-dealing - makes it the perfect symbol for transformation, which always involves the death of the old form.
Psychologically, fire represents the libido or psychic energy in its dynamic, transformative aspect. It can manifest as creative passion or destructive rage.
The theft of fire by culture heroes (Prometheus, Maui, Coyote) is one of the most widespread mythological motifs, representing humanity's acquisition of divine power and the dangers thereof.
